attributes.title: Stock take
attributes.description:
•    The physical stock counted compared to SAP warehouse balances indicated variances as follows; Bread -7.5 loaves, Yeast +3 Sachets, Polybags +1562 pieces. The rest stocks items had zero or minimal variances.

The table below illustrates the finding,
attributes.recommendation:
•    Stocks are well controlled, this should be maintained.
•    Regular stock take to ensure the stock balances align with the book balances.
attributes.effect:
•    Excess polybags is an indication of weak controls on packing materials.
•    Minimal stock variances on the rest of stock is an indication of good controls.

value: •    We shall tighten controls on all stock items to make sure we don’t have variation.
•    Stocks had minimal variances, we shall continue to monitor to ensure we don’t have variations.

•    In prior audit Poly bags had a cumulative variation of -307 pieces. It was also noted that two varieties had a significant variation 800 CTW had a variance of -1,397 pieces and 600 super Nutri had negative variance of -110 piece. Branch don’t produced 600 super Nutri.
•    Bread stock had a short fall of -83.5 loaves.
Current

•    Stock take was conducted on 15th March 2025 to establish whether the physical stocks were matching with the stock book balance generated from SAP system and whether internal controls on stocks were effective.
•    Stocks are well controlled, this should be maintained.
Operations/Production Department
To establish whether the physical stocks were matching with the stock book balance generated from SAP system and whether internal controls on stocks were effective.

attributes.title: Bread weight
attributes.description:
•    From the samples picked, bread underweight were noted as follows; 400g CT – 23%, 1500g W - 66%, 600g - 13%, and 800g W - 43%. 

The table below illustrates the findings;
attributes.recommendation:
•    The branch need to improve on production process to eliminate cases of underweights. 
•    Random weight spot checks of dough and packed bread to confirm bread produced is of the correct weight standards.
attributes.effect:
•     Presence of underweight bread exposes the company to penalties and fines if caught by weight and measure officials.
•    Underweight bread exposes the company to reputational risk through customer dissatisfaction.

value:
•    We will ensure that the supervisors manage the packing team well to eliminate cases of some varieties left to overcool.
•    Regular weight checks to ensure bread produced meets the correct weight standard.

•    Packers in this branch are a bit slow leading to bread overcooling and losing weight. 
•    We shall ensure this is managed through supervisors on duty.

•    In prior audit, all varieties weighed had underweight cases as follows;
400SN – 55%, 800W – 51%, 400W – 72%, 600W – 32%, and 1500W – 88%
Current

•    Bread weight was taken from a sample selected from packed bread ready to be dispatched to the market. The aim was to determine whether the bread dispatched to the market meets the required weight standards.

There were cases of underweight bread noted.  This exposes the company to;

•    Penalties and fines if caught by weight and measure officials.
•    Reputational risk through customer dissatisfaction.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure bread produced and dispatched to the market meets the recommended weight standards.

attributes.title: Bread damages
attributes.description:
•    It was noted that production damages were averaging at 0.32% of the production and market damages stood at 0.50% of the total sales. 

Production damages analysis;

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

 

Market damages analysis;
attributes.recommendation: •    The branch should improve on production processes to make sure bread produced is of good quality hence minimize cases of production damages.
attributes.effect: •    Production damages recorded for the period exceeded the set threshold exposing the company to a revenue forfeiture amounting to Kshs. 37,982.45

value: •    Production damages were as a result of oven breakdown.
•    We will monitor shift wise damages to ensure we don’t have negligence under production damages.
•    In the previous audit, it was noted that the overall production damages were 0.34% of bread produced while market damages were 0.54% of sales for the same period.
Current

•    Analysis of production and market damages was done for the period 15th Feb 2025 to 14th Mar 2025 to determine whether bread damages were within the desired percentages of 0.20% of the total production and 0.50% of the total sales.
Production damages exceeded the set limit of 0.2% of the total production while market damages were within the set limit of 0.5%.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure that damages are within the acceptable limits.

attributes.title: Mixing Charts Analysis
attributes.description: The table below shows summarized findings of the mixing chart analysis;
attributes.recommendation:
•    Branch need to put more effort to maximize use of the available production capacity.
•    Yield achievement should be maintained.
attributes.effect: •    By not achieving the set production capacity, it implies that the branch is not taking advantage of economies of scale.

value: •    Our production is planned based on the orders hence the shortfall in capacity utilization.
•    Low sales is main reason for not achieving the branch target of 150 bags per day.

•    In the previous audit, it was noted that the Average production was 119.45 bags per day representing 79.64% of target which is 150bags per day (Branch Capacity), Average yield was 192.31, and Utto consumption was 100%. And no remix were noted over the audit period.

An analysis of mixing chart summaries was done for a period of 28 days from 15th Feb 2025 to 14th Mar 2025, to confirm production data accuracy from mixing charts to cash flow and SAP, raw materials usage as per the set BOM and if the set production standards were achieved.
The branch achieved 74% of their production capacity which implies there was an unutilized production capacity of 26%
Operations/Production Department
To confirm production data accuracy from mixing charts to cash flow and SAP, raw materials usage as per the set BOM and if the set production standards were achieved.

attributes.title: Cash Verification
attributes.description:
•     It was noted that cash counted compared to cash flow balance had minimal negative variance of Kes -3.
•    There was one outstanding IOU of Kes 2000 advanced to the driver of motor vehicle KBV 290R for vehicle inspection.
attributes.recommendation: •    The branch cashier should maintain the cash controls in place

value: •    This is well noted
•    Well noted, to be maintained.
•    In the prior audit, the cashier was expected to have Ksh.178, 765.00, but cash counted was Ksh.178,765. A variance of +1shillings.
Verification of cash held at the cash office was done on 17th March 2025, to confirm cash held by the cashier and whether the set cash operation standards are adhered to.
The cash controls in place are adequate.
Finance Department
To confirm cash held by the cashier and whether the set cash operation standards are adhered to.

attributes.title: Production efficiency
attributes.description: Production analysis revealed that the branch achieved an efficiency of 4.36 bags per production worker.
attributes.recommendation: The branch management should ensure that workers are managed efficiently to eliminate cost associated with production inefficiencies.
attributes.effect: Failure to achieve production target efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker implies the company incurred unbudgeted labor cost amounting to Kes 25,634.65

value: We will monitor hired workers to make sure they achieve the efficiency.
Missed efficiency by small margin, this is attributed to shift cuts as a result of low demand.
In the prior audit, it was noted that production efficiency was 4.35 bags per production worker.

Production efficiency was calculated for period of 28 days from 15th Feb 2025 to 14th Mar 2025. The aim was to determine if the production workers hired were achieving the set production efficiency of 4.5 bags per worker.
The achieved efficiency was 4.36 bags per production worker, which is below the expected level of 4.5 bags per worker.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure optimal utilization of the production labor employed.

attributes.title: Packing Efficiency
attributes.description: Packing analysis revealed that the average slicing efficiency for the period was 87.93 crates per slicer, as illustrated below.
attributes.recommendation: Branch management should ensure slicers are hired based on the workload and also they should be push them to achieve the set efficiency.
attributes.effect: Slicing inefficiency resulted to increased cost of packing amounting to Kes 38,480.

value: We will continue to push slicers to achieve the recommended efficiency.
Our slicers are slow, we shall continue to push and monitor so as to improve on the efficiency.
In the prior audit, it was found that the packing efficiency was 89.23 crates per slicer
Slicing Efficiency was computed for 28 days from 15th February 2025 to 14th March 2025 to determine whether the set company standard of 97 crates per slicer was being achieved
The branch did not meet the set limit of 97 crates per slicer over the period.
Operations/Production Department
To ensure optimal utilization of the packing labor employed

attributes.title: Debtors Analysis
attributes.description: It was noted that, the total outstanding debtors amounted to Kes 770,402. Most of the outstanding balances are from active institutions and individual customers except for one material dormant institution - St. Paul's Amukura Boys' School Kes 142,526.
attributes.recommendation: The sales Rep and the sales crew should ensure that bread supplied is paid for on delivery except for customers with credit arrangements.
attributes.effect: Outstanding route balances with no security deposits can lead to bad debts and hence financial losses.

value: Sales Rep Comment – St. Paul’s Amukura boys’ school account was transferred to Bungoma. Most of our balances are current invoice and institution with existing credit terms.
An analysis of the route balances was done as at 15 March 2025 to ascertain the status thereof.
Sales Department
To ascertain the status of accounts receivables in the branch.

attributes.title: Fuel consumption analysis
attributes.description:
It was noted that all sales vehicles were saving on fuel consumption except for Kitale town route vehicle KCG 912G which had overconsumed by 3.7 litres.

The consumption analysis is as illustrated below.
attributes.recommendation: Branch manager should continue to ensure sales vans fuel consumption is within the set standards.
attributes.effect: Fuel consumption within the set standards which implies adequate controls are in place.

value: We shall continue to monitor vehicle consumptions
This well noted.
From the prior audit, it was noted that fuel consumption of all vehicles were within the set standard.
Motor vehicle fuel consumption analysis was done for the period 1st March 2025 to 14th March 2025. To evaluate compliance with set fuel standard for each vehicle.
Transport/Fleet Department
To ensure fuel consumptions are within the set standards and that the data kept by the branch manager is correct.
